string-array.name: wark_history
string-array.item: Built in the mid-twelfth centuryBuilt in the mid-twelfth century
In 1327, the castle twice held out against Scottish sieges
The powerful and influential Percy family was given the castle by the crown in the early 14th century
The Percy family helped Henry IV win the throne from Richard II. But the family later rebelled against the new king. The rebellion was defeated at the battle of Shewsbury.

string-array.name: dunstan_history
string-array.item: Built by the Earl Thomas of Lancaster in the early 14th century
Earl Thomas led an unsuccessful rebellion against King Edward II, causing him to be executed by the king. As a result, the castle was seized by the crown.
John of Gaunt, who founded the royal House of Lancaster which later took part in the Wars of the Roses, greatly expanded the castle in the late 14th century.
The castle was traded back and forth during the Wars of the Roses, which represented its strategic importance in the north of England. The damage sustained during these wars was never fully repaired.

string-array.name: rising_history
string-array.item: Built during the mid 12th century by an Anglo-Norman lord
The castle was famously the home of Queen Isabella after the accession of her son, Edward III, to power.

Queen Isabella joined forces with Roger Mortimer to rebel and bring down her husband Edward II. She ruled along with Mortimer for a short period before her son, Edward III, seized control of the nation.
The castle quickly became valued for its hunting facilities rather than its strategic importance.

string-array.name: berk_history
string-array.item: Built on a key route between London and the Midlands by the Normans in the 11th century
Thomas Becket was granted the castle in the 12th century, before falling out with the King and being stripped of the castle.
The castle was besieged by the French Prince Louis in 1216. He was attempting to take control of the crown after the death of King John.
The castle was taken apart for stone as early as the mid 16th century, and is now a sparse ruin.

string-array.name: warwick_history
string-array.item: The castle was originally a wooden fort construction by William I
The Beauchamp family controlled the castle for much of the medieval period and were influential on the course of English history.

The castle passed to Richard Neville after the Beauchamp line ended. He was known as the kingmaker for he often held the balance of power during the Wars of the Roses, and was therefore able to gather much power to himself.
The castle was used as a military base up until the early 17th century, when it was converted into a country house.

string-array.name: bamburgh_history
string-array.item: The site was formally a stronghold of Celtic Britons and Anglo-Saxons.
The fort was destroyed by the Vikings only around 70 years before the arrival of the Normans in England.
The Normans later constructed a new castle on this site, which has evolved into what can be seen today.
The castle was the first in England to be defeated by artillery during a siege in the Wars of the Roses.

string-array.name: alnwick_history
string-array.item: Alnwick Castle was first built by Norman lords following William the Conqueror’s invasion of England.
The castle was sieged many times by the Scottish throughout the 12th century, with David I of Scotland successfully capturing it in 1136.
The powerful and influential Percy family took control of the castle in the 13th century, who turned the castle into a major fortress in the England-Scotland border region.
The castle was used as a stand-in for Hogwarts during the Harry Potter films

string-array.name: dover_history
string-array.item: This version of Dover castle was built in the 11th century.
However, due to its strategic importance, fortifications on this site likely pre-date the Roman invasions.
The castle was rebuilt significantly during the Napoleonic wars, and was occupied by British forces to defeat against a potential French Calais-Dover invasion.
Dover castle was a military command centre during the second world war. The evacuation of Dunkirk was directed from this site.

string-array.name: raby_history
string-array.item: Built by the Neville family in the late 14th century
Cecily Neville was born In the castle, her children included King Edward IV and Richard III, the Yorkist kings of England.
The Neville family attempted to support the claim of the catholic Mary, Queen of Scots, to the English throne. Following this, the castle was taken into royal ownership.
The castle is still lived in today.

string-array.name: caen_history
string-array.item: The first stone building was built by Edward I of England following his attempts to control Wales.
The castle was sacked in 1294 during a Welsh rebellion against English rule.
With the accession of the Tudor family to the crown in 1485 and due to their Welsh heritage, relations between Wales and England improved so the castle was no longer an important military base.
Despite its poor condition, the royalist controlled castle was sieged several times during the English civil wars.

string-array.name: carlisle_history
string-array.item: This castle was built in Norman times and sits close to the ruins of Hadrian’s wall.
During Roman times, a fort was built on this same site.
The castle was captured by David, King of Scotland, in the early 12th century. Due to its strategic location on the Anglo-Scottish border it was sieged many times in the middle ages.
The castle was the site of a bloody siege during the Wars of the Roses, with the Lancastrians teaming up with the Scots to seize the castle from the Yorkists.

string-array.name: conway_history
string-array.item: Built by Edward I in the late 13th century, it was one of many castles built in the North of Wales during this time.
It repelled many welsh sieges, including in 1294 when Madog ap Llywelyn failed to take the castle.
Richard II took refuge at the castle in 1399, as his power slipped away following defeat by the future King Henry IV.
The castle was dismantled significantly following the English civil wars as Parliament did not want it used in further revolts.

string-array.name: bodiam_history
string-array.item: Built by one of Edward III’s knights in the late 14th century, it is unusual in that is has no keep.
It was originally constructed to provide protection against the French during the 100 years war.

The castle’s owner was a supporter of the House of Lancaster during the Wars of the Roses. However, it was taken by Yorkist forces during the wars and only returned to its owner when Henry VII took the crown, effectively ending the Wars of the Roses.
The castle was dismantled in the 17th century, but in the 19th century began a gradual restoration to its current state.

string-array.name: rochester_history
string-array.item: This castle was founded just after the Norman conquest of Britain.
The castle was sieged by King John in 1215. He managed to bring down a corner of the keep and was later able to starve the defenders into surrender.

Following repair, the castle was again sieged in 1264 by Simon de Montfort, who was rebelling against the king. Their siege was unsuccessful as royal reinforcements forced off the attackers. However, the castle surrendered when the rebels crushed the king’s forces on the battlefield.
The castle never fully recovered from these two sieges, and gradually fell into a state of disrepair.

string-array.name: stirling_history
string-array.item: The castle is built on a large volcanic rock above the river Forth, and is on a very strategically important site.
Stirling castle was the site of much fighting during the Wars of Scottish independence, involving characters such as William Wallace, Robert the Bruce, Edward I and Edward II.
During these wars the battles of Stirling Bridge and Bannockburn took place. These were two of the greatest victories for the Scottish over the English.
James II infamously murdered Earl Douglas at Stirling castle.

string-array.name: edin_history
string-array.item: Built on a commanding rock, this site has been an important strategic location since at least Roman times.
This castle is the most besieged castle in Britain, due to its important strategic location and the constant fighting between the English and Scottish throughout the middle ages.
The castle formerly housed the Scottish royal treasury as it was seen as the safest place in the country to hold such valuable artifacts.
Bonnie Price Charlie was the last person to try and take the castle. He was unsuccessful, eventually giving up and marching into England to press his claim to the throne.

string-array.name: durham_history
string-array.item: The castle was first built in 1072 by William the Conqueror.
The castle was besieged during one of the many northern rebellions against Norman rule in 1080.
The castle was put into the hands of Prince-Bishop’s for much of its early medieval history. The role of these bishops was to act as a buffer between England and Scotland.
The Bishop of Durham still maintains offices at the castle.

string-array.name: conis_history
string-array.item: The estates of Conisbrough were in the hands of King Harold prior to his defeat by the Norman king William the Conqueror.
The Normans originally built a wooden castle here, but it was upgraded to stone in the late 12th century by Hamelin Plantagenet, the illegitamte half-brother of King Henry II.
Thomas, Early of Lancaster, controlled the castle in 1322 when he rebelled against King Edward II. He was defeated and executed, and the castle was seized personally by King Edward.
During the Wars of the Roses, the castle was the personal property of Richard of York, and later of his son King Edward Iv.

string-array.name: lancaster_history
string-array.item: The castle is part of the Duchy of Lancaster, which is owned by the Monarch of the UK.
The caslte was damaged by Scottish invasions in 1322 and 1389.

The parliamentarians captured the castle early in the English Civil War. In response, the king sent an army to retake the city of Lancaster, including the castle. They were unsuccessful and the castle and city remained under parliament control.

string-array.name: york_history
string-array.item: Clifford\'s tower was originally a wooden castle built on the orders of William the Conqueror.
In 1069, the castle was captured an partially destroyed by an anglo-saxon and viking alliance rebelling against William I. The events at York led to the "Harrowing of the North" by William.
The castle was upgraded to stone in the middle of the 13th century by Henry III.
The caslte was an important military base during the Anglo-Scottish wars from 1298 to 1338.

string-array.name: cardiff_history
string-array.item: The original Motte and Bailey castle was built on this site shortly after the Norman invasion of England.
The castle was rebuilt in stone in the 12th century.
The welsh prince Owain Glyndwr took the castle in 1404 during his rebellion against English control of Wales.

string-array.name: pontefract_history
string-array.item: The castle was originally constructed by the Normans shortly after their conquest of England.
Thomas, Earl of Lancaster, was executed outside of the walls of the castle following his failed rebellion against King Edward II. Edward was dining in the great hall as the execution was carried out.
The castle was part of the house of Lancaster, and was seized by Richard II when he banished Henry Bolingbroke. Henry later returned, overthrew Richard and became Henry IV.
Richard II was held at the castle, and was likely starved to death whilst at the castle.

string-array.name: prudhoe_history
string-array.item: Built in the late eleventh century to defend against Scottish incursions into England.
The castle was sieged many times during Anglo-Scottish wars in the early middle ages. However, it was never taken by the Scottish, the only castle in Northumberland with that honour.
In 1381 the castle was purchased by the powerful Percy family, who descended from William de Percy, who was a Norman supporter of William the Conqueror.

In 1403-1405 the Percy family rebelled against King Henry IV, and so the castle was taken by the king and granted to his brother, the Duke of Lancaster. However, the Percy family were restored to their ownership of the castle by Henry VII in 1470.

string-array.name: richmond_history
string-array.item: The original castle was constructed on this site by the Norman invaders after the harrying of the north, when William I divided the north Yorkshire lands among his loyal followers.
Henry II seized the castle in 1158 and completed the keep which can still be seen today.
The castle’s ownership frequently changed hands as the castle was owned by the Dukes of Brittany in France. Often when tensions with the French flared up, the castle confiscated by the English crown.
In 1372, ownership of the castle was fully passed to the English crown.

string-array.name: lewes_history
string-array.item: Originally built after the Norman invasion to dominate the port of Lewes, which was an important port in Saxon England.
The battle of Lewes took part nearby, where the rebel Simon de Montfort defeated the royalist forces, and became de facto ruler of England.
The crown invested significantly in the castle in the early 14th century to protect against raids from the French, who England was currently fighting the 100 years’ war against.
During the Peasants’ Revolt in the late 14th century, the castle was attacked by rioters and looted.

string-array.name: oxford_history
string-array.item: Built shortly after the Norman invasion, the first stone fortifications were built as early as 1073.

During the war of succession between King Stephen and the Empress Matilda, Matilda was surrounded by Stephen’s forces at the castle. However, she escaped by being lowered over the castle walls and creeping away through the snow whilst wearing a white nightdress.
During the Baron’s revolt against King John in 1216, the castle was besieged successfully by John.
The castle was largely destroyed by the parliamentarians after the English civil war, as they did with many of the countries castles which they saw as Royalist symbols.

string-array.name: maiden_history
string-array.item: Maiden castle is an Iron Age hill fort. It was expanded around 450 BC to become the largest hill fort in Britain.
A hill fort is essentially a fortified hill-top settlement, using earth works to secure the settlement.
Maiden caslte, unusually for hill forts, was still occupied during the Roman conquest of Britain in AD 43. After the Roman conquest, the site was abandoned.
In the late 4th century a religious structure was built on the hill, most likely worshipping a combination of Roman and British gods.

string-array.name: tamworth_history
string-array.item: Tamworth was an important Anglo-saxon town in the kingdom of Mercia, and was the chief residence of King Offa of Mercia, who was an extremely powerful Anglo-Saxon king in the 8th century.

Successive Viking attacks destroyed much of the town, and it only recovered after the Norman conquest when the Norman steward Robert Despenser built a Norman motte and bailey castle on the site of the old Anglo-Saxon defences.

The Marmion family, also supporters of the Norman royal family, ruled the castle after Robert died and left the castle to his niece. This family controlled the castle until 1294 and they were responsible for turning it into the stone building seen today, although many additions were made to the castle in later years.
The castle was garrisoned by Royalists during the English Civil War, but was captured by Parliament in 1643 and held by them for the rest of the war.

string-array.name: lincoln_history
string-array.item: Lincoln sits on high ground overlooking a generally flat landscape, this strategic importance was recognised by the Romans who built a legionary fortress on this site.
A major Norman castle was then constructed on this site following the invasion of William the Conqueror.

During the war for the crown between Stephen and Matilda, Lincoln Castle was besieged by Stephen. He was then attacked by a force loyal to Matilda, and was defeated and imprisoned, allowing Matilda to rule England for around 18 months.

Following the signing of Magna Carta, Lincoln Castle was the site of another battle between Henry III and the future Louis VIII of France, who had earlier been invited over to England to fight against King John. Henry III decisively won the battle and it was a turning point in the war against Louis and the English barons who supported him.

string-array.name: colchester_history
string-array.item: Colchester Castle was built by the Normans after the invasion of William the Conqueror.
Colchester was a major Roman centre, and the large size of the keep is due to the use of the masonry base of the Roman Temple of Claudius, which was the largest Roman temple in Britain.

King John besieged Colchester Castle during his war with the Barons, who garrisoned the castle with French troops sent over by Prince Louis of France. John successfully took the castle via negotiations with the defenders.
The castle was later used as a prison. In the mid-17th century, the Witchfinder General, Matthew Hopkins, used the castle to interrogate and imprison suspected witches.

string-array.name: restormel_history
string-array.item: Built in the South West of England, the castle was originally built by the Normans to try and control the area, which was a centre for Anglo-Saxon resistance following the Norman invasion in 1066.
Simon de Montfort seized the castle without a fight in 1264 as he took power from Henry III. Henry’s supporters took the castle back the next year.
The castle passed into the ownership of the crown in 1299, but was not extensively lived in.
The castle was in a state of disrepair from as early as the mid 14th century.

string-array.name: ludlow_history
string-array.item: Founded after the Norman conquest, Ludlow Castle was one of the first stone castles in England.

The castle was heavily involved in the war for the English crown between Stephen and Matilda. Stephen took the castle in 1139 and granted it to one of his knights. However, this knight later lost the castle to the de Lacy family during an inter-family conflict.

Prince Edward (the future Edward I) gathered his supporters at the castle in 1265, and was able to defeat Simon de Montfort and gain back power for his father Henry III. Simon had previously rebelled against the king and taken power for himself.
The castle was an important seat of power for the Yorkists during the Wars of the Roses, as the castle was inherited by the Duke of York in 1425.

string-array.name: berkeley_history
string-array.item: The fast castle was built here almost immediately after the Norman invasion in 1066.
Henry II granted a royal charter to the owner of the castle in 1153 to allow the owner to rebuild a more extensive castle on the site.

The deposed Edward II was held at Berkeley castle in 1327. During his time captive at the castle, his supporters attacked the castle and rescued him. This rescue was short-lived and he was returned to the castle shortly afterwards and he was likely murdered at the castle.

During the Civil War, Parliament captured the castle with the use of cannon. The castle was not allowed to be repaired following the civil war, as parliament saw castles as symbol of royal dominance of the country.

string-array.name: belvoir_history
string-array.item: Originally a Norman castle existed on this site, Belvoir was originally a royal manor until it was granted to Robert de Ros in 1257.

The Norman castle was ruined by the 15th century, and a new castle was built on the site by 1555. The castle was a Royalist stronghold during the English Civil War, even housing the King for a night during the war.
After the Civil War, parliament destroyed the castle and a stately home was built in its place by 1668.
The castle was rebuilt in the early 19th century by the Duke and Duchess of Rutland in the gothic revival style.

string-array.name: longtown_history
string-array.item: Longtown was originally home to a Roman fort, the ditch of which was deepened and widened to protect against welsh incursion into England in 1055.
A small Norman castle was built close to the site of the current castle shortly after the Norman conquest of England.
The castle was upgraded to stone in the 12th century, and that is the structure we see today.
The castle had fallen into disrepair by the early 15th century. However, Henry IV refortified the castle in 1403 in response to the Welsh uprising by Owain Glyndwr.

string-array.name: harlech_history
string-array.item: Harlech Castle was built by Edward I during his invasion of Wales in the late 13th century.

Owain Glyndwr, the last Welsh Prince of Wales, took the castle in 1404 and made it his headquarters for the rest of the uprising. However, by 1409 Owain was recaptured and Wales was back under the control of England.

The castle was held by the Lancastrians for much of the the Wars of the Roses, before it was captured by the Yorkists in 1468. It was the last major fortification held by the Lancastrians at that point and had been the launch-pad for many Lancastrian revolts against the Yorkist King Edward IV.

The damage done in the siege of 1468 was only repaired during the English Civil War, when the royalists repaired the castle. The castle was the last major royalist stronghold to surrender to parliament.

string-array.name: lindisfarne_history
string-array.item: The castle was built in 1550 mainly using stones from the Priory which was shut down and plundered by Henry VIII following the break with the Catholic church.
The union of England and Scotland reduced the importance of Lindisfarne castle, although it maintained a garrison.
In the civil war, Parliament captured the castle from the Royalists, and with it took control of the port on the island.
The castle was briefly captured by the Jacobites in 1715, before they were forced to run away on news of an approaching English force from Berwick.

string-array.name: launceston_history
string-array.item: Built just after the Norman invasion, this castle was the administrative centre of the earldom of Cornwall.
The castle was rebuilt in stone in the late-12th century.
The earldom of Cornwall, and the castle, passed to Henry III’s younger brother Richard in 1227. He reworked the castles defences using money from the Cornish tin mining industry.

The castle was briefing owned by Piers Gaveston, the controversial favourite of Edward II. However, by the time the castle passed into the hands of the son of Edward III, it was reported as being in poor condition.

string-array.name: totnes_history
string-array.item: Totnes was the site of a fortified burh in Devon during the Saxon times. Its strategic importance lead to it being raided many times by the Vikings.
Totnes castle was originally constructed by the Normans shortly after their invasion, likely following the rebellion against King William in the South West shortly after he took the English crown.
King John seized the castle from its legal owner during his reign and granted it to one of his supporters. After John’s death, however, it passed back to the legal owner.
The castle was significantly rebuilt in the early 14th century, however the castle fell into disrepair by the end of the Wars of the Roses.

string-array.name: wallingford_history
string-array.item: Built shortly after the Norman invasion, this castle was one of the most powerful royal castles in the 12th and 13th centuries.
The castle was held by supporters of Matilda during her war for the crown with Stephen. It was sieged many times, but never taken.
The castle was owned by King John during his reign, and he used it throughout his wars with the Barons.
Simon de Montfort captured the castle in 1264 and briefly used it to hold the royal family prisoner.

string-array.name: kenilworth_history
string-array.item: The castle was founded in the early 12th century by the then treasurer to Henry I.
Due to its strategic importance, Henry II took the castle into royal possession during a revolt against him by his son.

King John spent a lot of resources upgrading Kenilworth Castle after he was excommunicated. John had to cede he castle as part of his signing Magna Carta, and it only returned to royal possession during the reign of his son Henry III.
The castle is ruined because of the slighting of the castle following the English Civil War.

string-array.name: middleham_history
string-array.item: A motte and bailey castle was originally built in Middleham shortly after the Norman invasion of England.
The stone castle was likely built on the current site in the late 12th century.
The castle came into the hands of the Neville family in 1270, and eventually into the hands of Richard Neville, the Earl or Warwick, who was known as the kingmaker during the Wars of the Roses.
The future Richard III married Anne Neville and took the castle as his main home following the death of the Earl of Warwick. During his reign, Richard rarely if ever visited the castle.

string-array.name: beeston_history
string-array.item: The castle was built in the early 1220’s for the Earl of Chester. The castle is unusual as it does not have a keep, instead using natural features of the land to make the bailey’s themselves strongholds.
King Henry III inherited the Earldom of Cheshire and increased the size of the castle during his wars with the Welsh, where the castle was used to hold prisoners of war.
Henry gave the castle and the Earldom of Cheshire to his heir, and ever since it has been given to the heir to the throne.

The castle was in ruin at the start of the English Civil War, however, parliament repaired it and garrisoned it. The castle was lost to a tiny royal force, who crept into the castle at night. The parliamentarian castle governor was shot for his failure to hold the castle.

string-array.name: pendennis_history
string-array.item: Pendennis castle was built by Henry VIII as part of his fort building programme to protect against potential French invasion.
In the late 16th century, the keep and gun platform was expanded in response to a growing threat from catholic Spain.
The castle was taken by Parliament in 1646, during the English civil war, after a successful siege. The castle was a formidable fortress, and briefly housed Prince Charles during the war.
The castle saw service during both world wars, and was upgraded in response to the renewed French threat following the French revolution and rise of Napoleon.

string-array.name: portchester_history
string-array.item: Due to its strategic importance, a Roman fort was constructed on the site of the castle in the late 3rd century.
The fort was used by the Saxon’s to defend about Viking raids on the southern coast. Edward the Elder, son of Alfred the Great, took control of the castle for this purpose in 904.
The Normans built a later castle on this site, and it was a royal castle for a long period from 1154. It was besieged and taken by the French in 1216, but later was returned to English control.
Edward III gathered his army for his invasion of France in 1346. This army famously went onto to win a decisive victory at the Battle of Crecy.

string-array.name: dunnottar_history
string-array.item: The Scottish King Donald II was killed at Dunnottar during a Viking raid in 900. The castle was destroyed in the raid.
The castle was captured from an English garrison by William Wallace in 1297. Wallace burned the church where the English were hiding and destroyed the castle.
Mary, Queen of Scots visited the castle several times, including with her young son, the future James I of England.

Oliver Cromwell sieged the castle in 1651 during his campaign in Scotland after the English civil war. The castle held out for 8 months before surrendering upon the arrival of heavy cannons at the siege.

string-array.name: kenmure_history
string-array.item: The semi-independent Lords of Galloway possibly had a fortress on this site prior to the 13th century.
The core of the current castle was constructed in the 17th century by the Gordon family, who were made Viscounts of Kenmure by Charles I.
The 6th Viscount of Kenmure was executed for his role in the Jacobite rising of 1715. His estates, including the castle, were forfeit and the castle was in ruin by 1790.
The Gordon’s were granted the viscount status back in 1824, and the castle was modernised considerably during the 19th century.
